RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Outrigger DJ Operating LLC

Makena Gas Plant (Facility ID: 100000241053)



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Makena gas processing plant is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contractors working in the facility, our neighbors in the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is strongly supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility. The facility does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However, if an uncontrolled release does occur, the personnel at the facility will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the plant, and notify the necessary outside agencies.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Makena plant is a cryogenic natural gas processing plant which extracts hydrocarbon liquids from raw natural gas streams.  The raw natural gas streams are delivered via pipeline to the plant from the local gathering system.  After extraction of the hydrocarbon liquids, residue gas and these liquids are sold as products.  Products are transported from the plant via pipeline and truck.  There are no listed toxic substances which exceed their respective threshold quantities stored at this facility.



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Several storage vessels within the plant process were evaluated for the worst case release scenario.  Results of the worst case release scenario indicate that the process is subject to RMP Program Level 1 requirements.  



The scenario involves a vapor cloud explosion involving 268,104 pounds of a flammable mixture from the Condensate Storage Drum The entire inventory of this vessel is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion and impacting an area wi

th a 0.5-mile radius. The rest of the vessels that were evaluated are located within this radius and have a radius smaller than the WCS vessel discussed. One other vessel produced a 0.5-mile radius when modeled in RMP Comp; however, the Condensate Storage Drum is the largest vessel at the site. 



The facility is not located within a populated area; therefore, the WCS would not affect a public receptor and is considered part of a Program 1 process.  A consideration of the 0.5-mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

This plant is regulated by 29 CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals - PSM), 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), as well as other federal, state and local regulations which are in place to reduce the potential for the release of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.



This plant has implemented the PSM elements to facilitate accidental release prevention.  Process safety information, consisting of technical standards, specifications and levels, promotes safe process design and operation.  Process hazard analysis evaluates hazards against safeguards needed to mitigate likelihood of an accidental release. Process changes are managed through the management of change procedure, by considering the impact that a change will have on the rest of the process.  For new or significantly changed processes, a pre-startup safety review is conducted as a final check to enable safe start up.  



The employee participation program promotes the development of necessary expertise, experiences, judgment, and proactive initiative within the workforce.  A comprehensive training program ensures that employees are knowledgeable about the processes they are responsible to operate and control.  Operating procedures explain correct startup, operation and shutdown procedures for various equipment in the process.  The hot work program is in place to promote safety of job

s involving potential ignition sources.  The mechanical integrity program ensures that equipment is maintained, inspected and tested for ongoing safety.  A contractor safety evaluation program is in place to ensure hire of contractors that will not compromise job or facility safety.   



The facility has a policy of investigating every incident, which may have possibly resulted in a release, in order to prevent a similar accident from recurring.  The facility has established an audit procedure to assure the continued integrity of the prevention program.  



The prevention program includes the following elements:



Employee Participation

Outrigger Energy encourages employees to participate in each facet of process safety management and accident prevention. Employee participation activities range from updating and compiling technical documents to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis ("PHA") team. Employees have access to the information created as part of the gas plant RMP prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the PSM program manual that is maintained at the gas plant and addresses each accident prevention program element.  



Process Safety Information

Outrigger Energy maintains a variety of technical documents used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within the Company are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information for the Loving Gas Plant.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets ("SDS"). The Company ensures that the process is maintained within acceptable limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained pe

rsonnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



The Company also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis

Outrigger Energy has conducted a PHA to ensure that hazards associated with the various processes at the Makena Gas Plant are identified and controlled. Within the PHA, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The Company primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. The HAZOP methodology utilizes a systematic nodal approach to assess potential process deviations and associated risks.



The analyses are conducted using a team of people with operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when it believes such measures are necessary. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking is measured against the Outrigger Energy risk matrix to ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive appropriate attention.  



Operating Procedures

Outrigger Energy maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup,

(2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures shall be annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures will be kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.



The operating procedures are used to communicate safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) pipe break procedures for hazard mitigation before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Outrigger Energy has developed a comprehensive training program for the employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in gas plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, the operators will periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. These

trainings are documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.  



Contractors

Outrigger Energy may use contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Company has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform gas plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, the Company evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Additionally, gas plant personnel will periodically evaluate the performance of contract employers in complying with plant safety policies and procedures.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews ("PSSRs")

Outrigger Energy conducts a PSSR for each new facility or qualifying facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides a final check to ensure (1) that the construction and equipment satisfies design specifications and (2) that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify the aspects of readiness prior to startup of the process.  



Mechanical Integrity

Outrigger Energy has developed practices and procedures to maintain press

ure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.  



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency in a timely manner to assure safe operation.  



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. Outrigger Energy incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.



Management of Change

Outrigger Energy has developed a system to manage changes to the covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage new hazards, and (2) verify that existing controls have not been

compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated, as required, to incorporate the changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided the necessary training on the change prior to start-up of the affected process.  



Incident Investigation

Outrigger Energy promptly investigates each incident that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, environmental loss, and/or injury or death to an individual onsite or offsite. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence and forwards these results to gas plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked and promptly resolved.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with the employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA re-validations.



Compliance Audits

Outrigger Energy shall conduct compliance audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits shall be conducted at least every three years. Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops reports of findings that are forwarded to gas plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports shall be retained.



5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Makena Gas Plant is a new facility and has not had any RMP-reportable accidents with the last five years.



EM

ERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

This facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated with the local fire department for response to large accidental releases.  As a non-responding facility, the RMP emergency response program and emergency response plan requirements (40 CFR 68.95) are not applicable at this facility.  However, the facility does maintain an emergency response plan that serves as guidance for facility employees to notify first responders, secure critical operations before evacuation, evacuate the facility, and account for personnel, among other items.  Facility personnel are trained in procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in response to small accidental releases.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The plant personnel are continually developing new ways to improve the safety of the facility.  This is done through responsibility matrices and training which is a vital part of any safety program.  Training is conducted according to a systematic schedule.  All new and modified equipment is designed with appropriate safety controls and devices.
